articles.headline: Martha Stewart, Near Trial, Arranges Her Image
articles.snippet: Martha Stewart has used focus groups and retinue of advisers in million-dollar campaign to arrange her defense and improve image prior to going to trial on charges of misleading investigators and investors about her trade of 4,000 shares of Imclon...
articles.abstract: Martha Stewart has used focus groups and retinue of advisers in million-dollar campaign to arrange her defense and improve image prior to going to trial on charges of misleading investigators and investors about her trade of 4,000 shares of Imclone Systems shortly before company announced disappointing news; will appear in court on Jan 20 to watch selection of jury; her legal team has carefully tested government's case--and her own reputation--before sampling of kind of people who will be deciding her fate; she also has Web site which presents her side of case; lingering question is whether or not campaign has reached potential jurors (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before Martha Stewart steps into a courtroom today to watch the selection of a jury for her federal trial, she and her legal team will have carefully tested the government's case -- and her own reputation -- before a sampling of the kind of people who will be deciding her fate.
articles.byline: By Constance L. Hays and Leslie Eaton

articles.headline: Media Baron Goes to Court For Approval Of Stake Sale
articles.snippet: Conrad M Black asks Canadian court to issue injunction that would prevent board of Hollinger International from trying to block sale of his control of company; legal maneuver is Lord Black's latest effort to frustrate Hollinger's board, which rema...
articles.abstract: Conrad M Black asks Canadian court to issue injunction that would prevent board of Hollinger International from trying to block sale of his control of company; legal maneuver is Lord Black's latest effort to frustrate Hollinger's board, which remains furious about Lord Black's surprise agreement to sell his controlling stake to brothers David and Frederick Barclay and their company Press Holdings International; Hollinger's lawyers are trying to find ways to thwart deal; sale of controlling stake could have significant effect on Hollinger's ability to recover more than $200 million it has accused Lord Black of misappropriating as well as company's effort to restructure itself; chart; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Escalating an increasingly bitter fight, Conrad M. Black asked a Canadian court yesterday to issue an injunction that would prevent the board of Hollinger International from trying to block his sale of control of the company.
articles.byline: By Geraldine Fabrikant and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Little Familiar With Setbacks, Dean Stumbles
articles.snippet: Howard Dean marks first loss of his charmed political life with pledge that 'we will not quit now or ever'; appears before fiery crowd in West Des Moines, Iowa, waving American flag and shouting himself hoarse; appears to readopt some of growling,...
articles.abstract: Howard Dean marks first loss of his charmed political life with pledge that 'we will not quit now or ever'; appears before fiery crowd in West Des Moines, Iowa, waving American flag and shouting himself hoarse; appears to readopt some of growling, angry outsider tone that propelled his earlier insurgency, listing states where he plans to fight next rounds: New Hampshire, South Carolina, Massachusetts and North Carolina; until couple of weeks ago Dean seemed almost invincible and on his way to clear-cut victory in Iowa; his third-place finish comes after months of near-constant attacks by several of his Democratic rivals; endorsements from Sen Tom Harkin and former Vice Pres Al Gore, two of nation's largest unions and 35 members of Congress seemed to complicate Dean's message more than help spread it; many Democrats say Dean's remark following capture of Saddam Hussein, that United States was no safer, led many to question whether he could take on president on critical issue of terrorism (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: He burst into the ballroom, fists thrust in the air, and slapped a string of high-fives with the dozens of labor union members standing onstage. He grabbed hold of Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa and yanked his hand up, too. He whipped off his suit coat and rolled his sleeves up as far as they would go.

articles.headline: Annan Signals He'll Agree To Send U.N. Experts to Iraq
articles.snippet: Secretary General Kofi Annan gives strong indications that he would accept request to send United Nations experts to Iraq, move that could help end stalemate over how to turn over authority to Iraqi-led government; top American, British and Iraqi ...
articles.abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan gives strong indications that he would accept request to send United Nations experts to Iraq, move that could help end stalemate over how to turn over authority to Iraqi-led government; top American, British and Iraqi officials from Baghdad meet with him at UN after months of ill will between US and UN, which refused to authorize Bush administration's decision to use military action in Iraq; Annan strikes cooperative yet cautious stance, but diplomats say he appears likely to decide quickly to approve request; United Nations election experts are already being briefed on complicated political plans by which occupation authority hopes to transfer power to Iraqis on June 30; participants in UN meeting say representative of Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, who has insisted on direct elections, says he would accept conclusions of UN experts; US maintains there is not enough time to organize direct elections; photo (M)

articles.headline: Private Health Plans to Receive Record Increase From Medicare
articles.snippet: Pres Bush will increase Medicare payments to health maintenance organizations and other private health plans by record 10.6 percent, seeking to reverse exodus of private plans from Medicare programs; goal is to persuade HMO's to enter Medicare mar...
articles.abstract: Pres Bush will increase Medicare payments to health maintenance organizations and other private health plans by record 10.6 percent, seeking to reverse exodus of private plans from Medicare programs; goal is to persuade HMO's to enter Medicare market and increase benefits for elderly; increase is five times as large as typical annual increase in recent years; administration is trying to enhance competition and efficiency in Medicare marketplace by tripling enmrollment in private plans within three years; many insurance executives decided they could no longer do business with program because their Medicare-related costs have been rising 10 percent a year, while Medicare payments have risen only 2 percent annually in recent years; Bush administration predicts that Medicare law enacted last month will encourage people to enroll in HMO's and similar private plans; new law creates prescription drug benefit and gives private health plans larger role in program (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: President Bush will increase Medicare payments to health maintenance organizations and other private health plans by a record 10.6 percent in an effort to persuade them to enter the Medicare market and increase benefits for the elderly, administration officials say.

articles.headline: Shattering Iowa Myths
articles.snippet: Analysis of Iowa caucus results; for voters there, Sen John Kerry showed himself to be what he says he is: reassuring establishment candidate with war hero's record, solid policy positions and broad enough experience in government to be strong cha...
articles.abstract: Analysis of Iowa caucus results; for voters there, Sen John Kerry showed himself to be what he says he is: reassuring establishment candidate with war hero's record, solid policy positions and broad enough experience in government to be strong challenger to Pres Bush; surprise second-place showing by Sen John Edwards reflects voters' similar judgments about how he would compete against Bush, and makes him fresh force to contend with, especially in South Carolina; third-place finish of Howard Dean evaporates sense of inevitability he once sought, and his fiery concession speech contrasts sharply with Kerry's husky Iowa, I love you,' and Edwards's soft, smiling speech; Dean still has more money than any rival, strong operation in New Hamsphire, which votes next week, and legions of supporters who are sure to join him in fighting back; only definitive development in Iowa is Rep Richard A Gephardt's distant fourth-place finish, which spells end of his quest for White House and probably his political career (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: For Iowa Democrats, Senator John Kerry showed himself to be what he has argued all along he was: the reassuring establishment candidate with the war hero's record, solid policy positions and broad experience in government to be a strong challenger to President Bush. He shattered conventional Iowa wisdom that organization is all.

articles.headline: Market Place; Is It the Sale of a Media Empire, Or a Desperate Negotiating Ploy?
articles.snippet: Article on whether Canadian media mogul Lord Conrad M Black's decision to sell controlling stake in his Hollinger International Inc to brothers David and Frederick Barclay actual sale or desperate negotiating ploy by Black to prevent Hollinger's b...
articles.abstract: Article on whether Canadian media mogul Lord Conrad M Black's decision to sell controlling stake in his Hollinger International Inc to brothers David and Frederick Barclay actual sale or desperate negotiating ploy by Black to prevent Hollinger's board from recovering more than $200 million that it has accused Black of misappropriating (Market Place column) (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Is this a sale, or is it a final negotiating ploy from a man who never thought he could lose control of his press empire but ran into a buzz saw of opposition that culminated in an American court's stripping him of the right to use his controlling stake for his own purposes?

articles.headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
articles.snippet: Jury Selection to Begin In Martha Stewart Trial  Jury selection begins today in the federal trial of Martha Stewart, who is charged with conspiracy, obstruction of justice and securities fraud, all stemming from a 2001 stock trade.
articles.abstract: Jury Selection to Begin In Martha Stewart Trial  Jury selection begins today in the federal trial of Martha Stewart, who is charged with conspiracy, obstruction of justice and securities fraud, all stemming from a 2001 stock trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jury Selection to Begin In Martha Stewart Trial

articles.headline: Banker Faces German Court Over Pay Issue
articles.snippet: German court to open proceedings against Deutsche Bank chief executive Josef Ackermann and three other former directors of Mannesmann on charges that they approved payment of improper bonuses to its executives; guilty verdict for Ackermann would a...
articles.abstract: German court to open proceedings against Deutsche Bank chief executive Josef Ackermann and three other former directors of Mannesmann on charges that they approved payment of improper bonuses to its executives; guilty verdict for Ackermann would almost certainly force him to resign, not to mention expose him to fines and jail sentence of as much as 10 years; would also leave Germany's flagship bank leaderless at time banking industry is entering period of likely consolidation; at issue is whether Ackermann and Mannesmann directors violated trust of shareholders by awarding 57 million euros ($70 million) in severance bonuses to chief executive Klaus Esser and other senior managers (M)

articles.headline: BUSH TO PORTRAY LIBYA AS EXAMPLE
articles.snippet: Pres Bush, in his State of Union speech, will urge countries to follow example of Libya, which recently announced it would dismantle its nascent nuclear weapons program; administration attributes that step to Bush's confrontational stance toward n...
articles.abstract: Pres Bush, in his State of Union speech, will urge countries to follow example of Libya, which recently announced it would dismantle its nascent nuclear weapons program; administration attributes that step to Bush's confrontational stance toward nations seeking chemical, biological or nuclear weapons; say Iran, Sudan and to some extent Syria appear to be doing what they can to avoid confrontation with United States; with Iran and North Korea, administration has pursued diplomacy; administration officials acknowledge that military force would be far riskier to use against either country; Iran's reluctant agreement to let international inspectors explore nuclear facilities kept secret for 18 years seems at least partly driven by fear of attack; Syria has embraced pragmatic approach, saying Israel should first give up its nuclear program; North Korea remains stubborn and unyielding; its foreign minister has boasted to delegation of visiting Americans that as Bush tries to build pressure on it to disarm, it has time to add to its nuclear arsenal; CIA believes it has produced fuel for two or three more bombs while Bush was focused on Iraq; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years after President Bush described Iraq, Iran and North Korea as an ''axis of evil'' -- perhaps the signature phrase of his presidency -- his foreign policy aides contend that his uncompromising language and willingness to use military force have changed the behavior of potential enemies.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: KERRY WINS THE IOWA CAUCUSES; DEAN 3RD, FAR BEHIND EDWARDS
articles.snippet: Sen John Kerry wins Iowa caucuses, Sen John Edwards comes in second and Howard Dean, who just week ago was clear favorite, comes in distant third; Rep Richard A Gephardt finishes fourth, ending his second bid for presidency; Kerry comes from behin...
articles.abstract: Sen John Kerry wins Iowa caucuses, Sen John Edwards comes in second and Howard Dean, who just week ago was clear favorite, comes in distant third; Rep Richard A Gephardt finishes fourth, ending his second bid for presidency; Kerry comes from behind to win by presenting himself as strongest Democrat his party has to send up against Pres Bush next year; result is serious setback for Dean, who has campaigned intensely across state for more than year; he promises to battle on; survey of caucus voters suggests that Dean's central appeal--opposition to war in Iraq--did him little good; Edwards seems delighted if bit surprised by outcome; says voters responded to his relentlessly cheerful message, drawing unstated but obvious contrast with Dean; with 98 percent of precincts reporting, Kerry has nearly 38 percent of delegate support, Edwards gets 32 percent, Dean takes 18 percent and Gephardt picks up 10 percent; Rep Dennis J Kucinich gets 1 percent; Dean's showing raises questions about intriguing element of his candidacy: that he recruited thousands of first-time voters who could transform nature of American presidential politics; although half the voters were attending their first Iowa caucuses, 36 percent voted for Kerry, 22 percent for Dean and 24 percent for Edwards; photo; chart (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts won the Iowa caucuses here Monday, brushing aside the insurgent anti-war candidacy of Howard Dean by presenting himself as the strongest Democrat his party had to send up against President Bush next year.

articles.headline: Broader Health Coverage May Depend on Less
articles.snippet: Some policy makers and influential health care experts are saying that best way to give health coverage to more people is to give some people less; experiments in several states are establishing stripped-down packages of basic benefits intended to...
articles.abstract: Some policy makers and influential health care experts are saying that best way to give health coverage to more people is to give some people less; experiments in several states are establishing stripped-down packages of basic benefits intended to be affordable for employers and uninsured workers, including young, middle-class people who have dropped out of health insurance pool; some officials say government health benefits could be extended to more people if benefit package were narrower; idea is one of several ways officials, faced with tight budgets and impatient with federal government, are striving to address consequences of 43 million Americans' going without health coverage; basic-coverage idea is being tested in Utah, Oregon and Idaho and by counties in several other states; is also at core of plan that Maryland Gov Robert L Ehrlich Jr will be presenting to state's Legislature this week; map; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: With the number of uninsured Americans rising to new heights, some policy makers and influential health care experts are saying that the best way to give health coverage to more people is to give some people less.
